channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Omicron Variant Circles the Globe, African Nations Face Blame and Bans
item.description: With countries trying to close their doors to the new coronavirus variant, southern African officials note that the West’s hoarding of vaccines helped create their struggle in the first place.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Travelers checking a flight information board at Johannesburg’s international airport on Saturday. Many countries have banned travelers from southern Africa since the discovery of a new variant.

item.title: A Wine Rack on Rails? U.K. Businesses Seek Solutions to Shortages.
item.description: Two months after concerns about gas and food stocks caused ripples of anxiety, Britain continues to face problems in its supply chain. Distributors and retailers are looking for creative fixes.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A freight train is loaded with nearly 650,000 bottles of wine at Tilbury Docks, east of London.

item.title: Israel and Iran Broaden Cyberwar to Attack Civilian Targets
item.description: Iranians couldn’t buy gas. Israelis found their intimate dating details posted online. The Iran-Israel shadow war is now hitting ordinary citizens.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Tel Aviv, Israel. The personal data of about 1.5 million Israelis were exposed in two recent hacks attributed to Iran.

item.title: Honduras Election: What's at Stake
item.description: Hondurans head to the polls on Sunday, but widespread political violence during the campaign and questionable results from 2017 are looming large.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Vendors selling political party flags in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on Friday, ahead of Sunday’s national elections, which may be the most significant in a decade.

item.title: ‘You’re Not Helpless’: For London Women, Learning to Fight Builds Confidence
item.description: After a year marked by isolation, loneliness and violence in the city, many self-defense and martial arts gyms say they are seeing more interest from women.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Muay Thai class at Fightzone London.

item.title: Iran Clamps Down on Protests Against Growing Water Shortages
item.description: The crackdown came after the protests spilled over to at least one other city and a major protest on Friday loomed. Weather experts say 97 percent of the country is dealing with water scarcity issues.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Hamidreza Nikoomaram/Fars News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by the semi-official Fars News Agency showed farmers protesting against water shortages on the dry bed of the Zayanderoud River in Isfahan, Iran, this month.

item.title: They Twice Gave Up Everything to Flee Iraq. They Keep Getting Sent Back.
item.description: Bria Ali and her family have twice tried to make it to Germany, desperate for a better life. They are now back home with thousands of others who made it to Europe in recent months only to be deported.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Hawre Khalid for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bria Ali at her home in Erbil, Iraq, this month. Bria and her family were deported from Poland on Oct. 31 after crossing the Belarusian border.

item.title: A Tale of Culinary Reconciliation, Beside the Eiffel Tower
item.description: Two decades ago, Spain was the new France, leading gastronomic innovation. Now two iconic chefs have joined forces in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Spanish chef Albert Adrià, second from right, and the French chef Alain Ducasse, right, at their pop-up restaurant ADMO in Paris.

item.title: A Couple’s Dream of Reuniting in England Is Dashed in a Channel Disaster
item.description: A young Kurdish woman, Maryam Nuri, died with 26 others after making a desperate attempt to join her fiancé by crossing the English Channel from France on an inflatable boat.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Brazil’s President Lula Is Staging a Comeback. Can He Bring the Country Along?
item.description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president, has beat back a flurry of corruption cases and climbed to the front of next year’s presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: The epic rise and fall of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva’s political career seemed to parallel that of Brazil, the country he governed as a two-time president. Now he wants a chance to lead again.

item.title: Solomon Islands Protests: 3 Burned Bodies Found in Chinatown
item.description: The police were trying to determine if the charred remains found in the capital’s Chinatown district were linked to the protests, in which demonstrators set fire to buildings.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Stores were looted and set ablaze in Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands, on Friday.

item.title: Afghan Economy Nears Collapse as Pressure Builds to Ease U.S. Sanctions
item.description: Afghanistan’s economy has crashed since the Taliban seized power, plunging the country into one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a World Food Program health facility in Kandahar, Afghanistan, last month.

item.title: France-U.K. Acrimony Impedes Progress on Channel Crossings
item.description: Rather than working together to curb hazardous sea crossings, leaders of the two countries almost immediately fell into a familiar pattern of squabbling.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Migrants on a bus after their arrival in Dover in southeast England this week.

item.title: ‘Afghan Girl’ From 1985 National Geographic Cover Takes Refuge in Italy
item.description: Sharbat Gula, whose haunting portrait was featured by the magazine more than three decades ago, was evacuated to Rome after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: Britain's Sajid Javid Defends Response to Omicron Variant
item.description: The government stopped short of urging people to work from home or extending vaccine passports in England after two cases of the Omicron variant were detected.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Aaron Chown/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sajid Javid, Britain’s health secretary, on Sunday.

item.title: Portugal Soccer Match Abandoned After Covid Reduces Team to 9
item.description: Players from the Belenenses team criticized sporting officials for demanding the match go on, saying soccer had “lost its heart.”
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Belenenses players, right, during a huddle before the match.

item.title: The W.H.O. Skips Forward Two Greek Letters, Avoiding a Xi Variant
item.description: Under the World Health Organization’s system, the Omicron variant might have been called Nu or Xi, but only at the risk of ambiguity or diplomatic awkwardness.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: Collecting a swab from Bronwen Cook for a PCR test for the coronavirus before a flight to London, at O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg on Friday.

item.title: Laszlo Z. Bito, Scientist, Novelist and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
item.description: He fled communist rule in Hungary, discovered a treatment for glaucoma in the U.S., then became an author and a voice against authoritarianism in his homeland.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg

item.title: How did Omicron get its name?
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: Tulio de Oliveira at the Nelson Mandela School of Medicine in Durban, South Africa, last week. Mr. de Oliveira and members of his team announced the new Covid-19 variant.

item.title: U.K. Confirms Two Cases of Omicron Coronavirus Variant
item.description: The prime minister reimposed a mask mandate, saying ‘there are many things we just cannot know.’
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan and Isabella Grullón Paz

item.title: As Potential Omicron Variant Cases Emerge, an International Scramble to Shut It Out
item.description: Dutch health authorities say it’s likely the Omicron variant will be detected among 61 infected travelers from South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Social Media Photo Obtained By Reuters
item.media:description: Passengers awaiting Covid test results in Amsterdam’s Schiphol Airport, in an image shared on social media on Saturday.

item.title: How Did the New Variant Get Its Name?
item.description: The World Health Organization began naming the variants after Greek letters to avoid public confusion and stigma.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: Tulio de Oliveira at the Nelson Mandela School of Medicine in Durban, South Africa. Mr. de Oliveira and members of his team announced the new Covid-19 variant.

item.title: Germany Finds Suspected Omicron Variant Case
item.description: A couple returning from South Africa are Germany’s first confirmed Omicron cases. Italy confirmed a case in a traveler returning from Mozambique.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Travelers arriving at the airport in Munich on Saturday.

item.title: Omicron Variant Prompts More Countries to Restrict Travel from Southern Africa
item.description: Australia, Canada and Thailand are among the latest countries to restrict travelers from the region over concerns about the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, John Yoon, Yan Zhuang and Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Foreign tourists at an entry lane at an airport in Bangkok this month.

item.title: Netherlands Finds 61 Covid Cases on South Africa Flights
item.description: The passengers were in the air when the Netherlands announced travel restrictions on flights from southern Africa.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Health workers transporting passengers from South Africa who tested positive for the coronavirus to a quarantine hotel in Schiphol, the Netherlands, on Saturday.

item.title: Giving Thanks in Australia
item.description: It’s an odd affair outside America, but maybe the holiday will inspire more of us to pause and appreciate the gifts we’ve been given.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell
item.media:credit: Romulo Yanes for The New York Times.
item.media:description: Roast turkey with orange and sage.

item.title: British Columbia Flood Victims Come Together In Storm's Wake
item.description: A tour of the flood-ravaged parts of the province finds communities supporting each other following disaster.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: A house was left partly submerged after floodwaters rerouted the Coldwater River in Merritt, British Columbia.

item.title: Omicron Variant Prompts Travel Bans and Batters World Markets
item.description: Scientists do not yet know how dangerous the new Omicron variant is, but its many mutations set off alarms, lowering hopes of putting the pandemic in the past.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: People lining up to get on an overseas flight at O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg, South Africa, on Friday.

item.title: Seeking Backers for New Fund, Jared Kushner Turns to Middle East
item.description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law is trying to raise capital for his investment firm and is turning to a region that he dealt with extensively while in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly, David D. Kirkpatrick and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Jared Kushner’s talks with the Saudis about an investment in his private equity firm remain in flux.

item.title: New 'Omicron' Variant Stokes Concern but Vaccines May Still Work
item.description: The Omicron variant carries worrisome mutations that may let it evade antibodies, scientists said. But it will take more research to know how it fares against vaccinated people.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A resident of Alexandra township was tested for Covid-19 in Johannesburg last year.

item.title: South Africa Feels Punished for Alerting World to New Variant
item.description: Hours after South African scientists announced the existence of a troublesome new variant, Britain banned travelers from southern Africa. The United States and other nations quickly followed suit.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A lab at the Nelson Mandela School of Medicine in Durban. South African scientists alerted global health authorities on Thursday to a new variant.

item.title: A Mine Disaster in Russia Highlights Safety Shortfalls in Rush to Dig Coal
item.description: At least 46 miners were killed in an explosion at a Siberian mine. The director of the mine has been taken into police custody, along with five other administrators.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: People laying flowers at a monument to miners near Belovo, Russia, on Friday.

item.title: U.S. to Place Travel Restrictions on South Africa, Other Countries
item.description: Starting Monday, travelers from South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique and Malawi will be barred unless they are citizens or permanent residents.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: New pandemic-related travel restrictions will go into effect Monday.

item.title: Merck Says Its Covid Pill Is Less Effective in a Final Analysis
item.description: The drug, molnupiravir, reduced the risk of hospitalization and death in high-risk Covid patients by 30 percent. An earlier analysis had found a 50 percent reduction.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: An experimental Covid-19 treatment developed by Merck and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics appears to be less effective than initially reported.

item.title: Protesters in Martinique Fire at Police Officers and Journalists
item.description: Protests against the French island’s coronavirus protocols, requiring a health pass to enter most public venues, have been exacerbated by frustrations and anger over economic inequality with the mainland.
item.dc:creator: Léontine Gallois
item.media:description: French riot police clash with protesters at a barricade in Martinique on Thursday night.

item.title: Jakucho Setouchi, 99, Dies; Buddhist Priest Wrote of Sex and Love
item.description: Her more than 400 novels often drew on her own romantic affairs, and her translation of an 11th-century romantic Japanese classic sold millions of copies.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
item.media:description: Jakucho Setouchi in 2007 in her garden in Kyoto. “I think it’s good to be free,” she said, “and to have sex with anyone.”

item.title: U.S. officials are consulting with South African scientists on the variant.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing at the Johannesburg airport on Friday. Health officials around the world are responding to a new variant detected in South Africa.

item.title: Covid Restrictions Are Back at Some of Europe's Theaters
item.description: Strict controls on playhouses and music venues are returning as the continent deals with a new coronavirus wave.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: The Vienna State Opera is closed for a few weeks as part of a lockdown in Austria.

item.title: Iraqis Return From Belarus, but Some Say They Will Try Again to Reach the E.U.
item.description: “If I find a better and safe route, I will definitely try again,” said one of the more than 600 Iraqi migrants who came home on the government’s latest evacuation flights.
item.dc:creator: Yasmine Mosimann and Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Fresh Violence in Darfur Adds to Sudan’s Crises
item.description: At least 43 people have been killed in clashes in the area, the U.N. says, while the nation’s leaders are focused elsewhere, dealing with the fallout from a coup.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Security forces in 2016 in West Darfur, where deadly violence has again broken out.

item.title: A Times correspondent reports from a plane held on the tarmac in Amsterdam.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Passengers at the O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg wait for their flights Friday. Several nations moved to stop air travel from southern Africa because of a new Covid-19 variant detected there.

item.title: Stocks and Oil Drop Amid New Coronavirus Variant
item.description: Stocks and oil futures slumped, while investors sought safety in government bonds.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: The Spanish Stock Exchange in Madrid on Friday. European markets fell 2 to 3 percent or more.

item.title: Cozy Season Is Here
item.description: A guide to your post-Thanksgiving weekend.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch
item.media:credit: Mary Mathis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends in a rented cabin in Wisconsin.

item.title: Europe is Tested by Waves of Cases that Threaten its Progress Against Pandemic
item.description: The deteriorating situation is also worrisome for the United States, as trends in new Covid cases tended to follow Europe by weeks.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: The Christmas market in Bremen, Germany, on Thursday. With cases and deaths rising, many such markets have been canceled.

item.title: Coffee or Chai? At 2 Kolkata Cafes, ‘Adda’ Is What’s Really on the Menu
item.description: Unrestricted talk, or “adda,” is the main draw at two storied cafes that are at once museums to the city’s intellectual history — and places for debate.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Indian Coffee House in Kolkata, India, has a storied history as a place for intellectuals to gather, and debate.

item.title: ‘Today’s Outfit Is Confidence’: Atypical TikTok Star Enchants Mexico
item.description: Middle-aged and scarred, a Mexican journalist is breaking the mold of social media influencers with a message of pure positivity that resonates in dark times.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: The videos of Martha Izquierdo, a journalist and cancer survivor, have earned tens of millions of TikTok likes.

item.title: New Covid Variant: What Scientists Know About Omicron
item.description: Scientists don’t know how effective vaccines will be against the new variant flagged by a team in South Africa, which displays mutations that might resist neutralization.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: More than 40 percent of adults in South Africa have received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccination.

item.title: Hong Kong Records Two Cases of Variant Detected in South Africa
item.description: The discovery could complicate efforts to reopen the border between the territory and the Chinese mainland.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Pedestrians wearing face masks in Hong Kong.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A concerning new variant.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vaccination rates in South Africa are falling far short of the nation’s goal, only administering 130,000 out of a daily goal of 300,000.

item.title: Russian Mine Blast Kills Dozens, Among Them Rescuers
item.description: Investigators said a gas buildup at a Siberian mine with a history of problems led to the deaths of at least 52 people.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kemerovo Region Government Press, via Agence France-Presse— Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescue workers arriving at the Listvyazhnaya coal mine Thursday. The photograph was provided by the regional government.

item.title: Abuses Under Gambia’s Ex-Ruler Should Be Prosecuted, Inquiry Says
item.description: A commission’s long-awaited investigation reported widespread human rights violations, but it is not clear if anyone will be charged with crimes.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh and Ruth Maclean
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Yahya Jammeh, then president of Gambia, at a rally in 2016.

item.title: Britain to Ban Flights From Six African Nations as Variant Identified
item.description: The British health secretary said the ban takes effect on Friday. Earlier on Thursday, South African scientists said they had identified a new variant.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: A worker sanitizes a sign at the international arrivals area of Heathrow Airport in London.

item.title: Undeterred by Channel’s Perils, Desperate Migrants Still Plan to Cross
item.description: The number of migrants setting off into the English Channel by boat has soared in recent months. The deaths Wednesday of at least 27 people trying to make the crossing illustrate how dangerous it is.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Norimitsu Onishi
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: A migrant praying at a makeshift camp near Calais, France, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A French rush for boosters.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A vaccination center in Nantes, France, last month.

item.title: South Africa Identifies New Variant of Coronavirus
item.description: Within hours of the announcement, Britain, Israel and Singapore had restricted travel from South Africa and some nearby countries.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, Andrés R. Martínez and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Vaccination rates in South Africa are falling far short of the nation’s goal, administering only 130,000 out of a daily goal of 300,000.

item.title: Will Germany’s ‘Debt Brake’ Stop Its Green Ambitions?
item.description: The new government has big plans to modernize the economy and switch to renewable energy. But the question remains how it will pay for it.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Olaf Scholz, center, the next prime minister, visiting areas damaged by floods in July.

item.title: A Native New Yorker Wrangles Pikachu in Thanksgiving Parade
item.description: Decked in a white jumpsuit and blue smock with a Pikachu cartoon on it, George Gustines maneuvered the huge blowup cartoon character down New York’s streets on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pikachu balloon makes it’s way down the parade route.

item.title: Thousands gathered to watch the first full Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade since the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands returned to watch the parade in person.

item.title: Ethiopian Leader Heads to Front Line as War Threatens to Widen
item.description: Two years after receiving the Nobel Peace Prize, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed’s claim that he was going into battle reflected both resolve and vulnerability.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Supporters of the Ethiopian government holding a placard of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed at a rally in Addis Ababa this month.

item.title: The Macy's Thanksgiving Day brings back some business to the area
item.description: Business was brisk for some as the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade returned to New York City. Delis, supermarkets, and even a man selling a turkey hat were overjoyed by the thousands of spectators.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turkey hats and other festive attire brought out decked out spectators for the parade.

item.title: Thanksgiving Air Travel Doubles, Nearly Hitting 2019 Levels
item.description: About 2.3 million people passed through security at airports on Wednesday, more than twice as many as in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: Travelers at Ronald Reagan National Airport outside Washington on Wednesday. It was the busiest day for airports across the United States since the pandemic began.

item.title: A Day in the Life of a Macy's Thanksgiving Parade Balloon Handler
item.description: Growing up, George Gustines had fond memories of a Sesame Street float and a vague recollection of one with Marvel heroes and villains. This year he wrangled the Pikachu balloon.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.media:description: The Pikachu balloon is prepped for the parade.

item.title: France Make All Adults Eligible for Boosters Amid Covid Surge
item.description: The French health minister said the latest wave of cases would be worse than the one during the summer. Adults will need a booster for their health pass to remain valid.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A vaccination center in Nantes, France, last month.
